我们之前已经多次写过这方面的文章：谷歌积极扼杀服务的声誉正在损害公司的品牌。谷歌推出的任何新产品都不再乐观，而是充斥着关于何时关闭的评论。这完全是 Google 自己造成的问题，但它又是另一个阻碍投资（时间、金钱或数据）最新的 Google 产品的障碍。 Google Stadia 今天面临的广泛怀疑就是一个很好的例子。一个有类似问题的谷歌部门是谷歌云平台，它要求公司和开发人员构建由谷歌云基础设施支持的产品或服务。与 Google 的其他部分一样，由于 API 很快被弃用，Cloud Platform 以不稳定着称，这使得托管在 Google 平台上的任何项目都需要不断更新以跟上最新的变化。不过，谷歌云希望通过新的“企业 API”名称来解决这个问题。企业 API 基本上有一个路线图，承诺某些 API 的稳定性。谷歌说，“负担在我们身上：我们的工作原则是，只要客户积极使用它，就不会删除任何功能（或以不向后兼容的方式进行更改）。如果弃用或破坏性更改是不可避免的，那么我们的负担是尽可能轻松地进行迁移。”如果 Google 确实需要更改 API，客户现在将收到至少一年的通知以及工具、文档和其他材料。 Google 继续说：“为了确保我们遵循这些原则，我们对 API 引入的任何更改都由产品和工程主管的集中委员会进行审查，并遵循严格的产品生命周期评估。”尽管是世界上最大的互联网公司之一，并且基本上定义了现代云基础设施的样子，但谷歌在云基础设施市场的表现并不好。 Canalys 以 7% 的市场份额将谷歌排在第三位，仅次于微软 Azure（19%）和市场领导者亚马逊网络服务（32%）。有传言（根据 The Information 的一份报告）谷歌云平台实际上面临着 2023 年的最后期限，以击败 AWS 和微软，否则将面临失去资金的风险。前谷歌员工史蒂夫耶格去年在一篇题为“亲爱的谷歌云：你的弃用政策正在杀死你”的帖子中阐述了谷歌云平台的问题。谷歌的声明似乎触及了这篇文章所强调的大部分内容，比如缺乏文档和支持，API 升级的无休止的跑步机，以及谷歌云对向后兼容性的普遍忽视。 Yegge 认为，像 Windows、Java 和 Android 等成功的平台（Yegge 说这个群体与更大的 Google 文化隔离开来）在很大程度上归功于他们对平台稳定性的承诺，并且从不破坏任何东西。 AWS 是市场领导者，部分原因是它被认为比谷歌云平台稳定得多。 Protocol 报道称，Google 副总裁 Kripa Krishnan 在公告期间实际上被问到她是否熟悉由 Cody Ogden 运营的 Killed By Google 网站和 Twitter 帐户。报告称，克里希南“忍不住笑了”，并说，“从互联网上的许多来源来看，我们很明显表现不佳。”谷歌云平台对谷歌声誉的认识、限制对客户干扰的措施以及它对哪些产品比其他产品更稳定的沟通，感觉就像是公司其他部门的榜样。许多 Google 产品目前都担心它们会被关闭，而且通常这足以让人们寻求其他替代方案。解决这个问题的主要方法只是缓解——即，停止关闭如此多的东西，一直。但紧随其后的是沟通——只需告诉人们您对未来支持的计划是什么。谷歌似乎没有问题为其硬件设备上的软件提供公共路线图。 Pixel 手机和 Chromebook 都有其软件的公开支持声明，显示了设备可以依赖支持的最低（这是最低限度！）日期。例如，我们知道 Pixel 5 至少会在 2023 年 10 月之前继续接收更新。谷歌无法立即解决其杀死产品和服务的声誉，但这样的沟通可以帮助用户和公司缓解一些犹豫在投资 Google 产品时越来越有感觉。如果你长期不打算杀死一个产品，那就说出来！告诉 Google 用户和公司合作伙伴哪些产品是稳定的，哪些是夜间实验。
当然，要使其发挥作用，Google 必须切实遵守其做出的任何公开承诺，以便人们相信它会兑现承诺。最近，该公司没有这样做。它承诺为 Android Things（Android 的物联网版本）提供三年支持。它没有兑现这一承诺。相反，谷歌仅在一年后就结束了操作系统更新。如果谷歌真的想修复其不稳定的声誉，它需要一个多年的旅程。
note_en:
We've written about this several times before: Google's reputation for aggressively killing services  is hurting the company's brand. Any new product launch from Google is no longer met with optimism but instead is inundated with comments about when it will be shut down. It's a problem entirely of Google's own making, but it's yet another barrier that discourages investing (either time, money, or data) in the latest Google thing. The  wide skepticism faced by Google Stadia today is a great example.
 A Google division with a similar problem is Google Cloud Platform, which asks companies and developers to build a product or service powered by Google's cloud infrastructure. Like the rest of Google, Cloud Platform has a reputation for instability thanks to quickly deprecating APIs, making any project hosted on Google's platform require continual updating to keep up with the latest changes. Google Cloud wants to address this though, with a new " Enterprise API" designation.
  Enterprise APIs basically get a roadmap that promises stability for certain APIs. Google says, "The burden is on us: Our working principle is that no feature may be removed (or changed in a way that is not backwards compatible) for as long as customers are actively using it. If a deprecation or breaking change is inevitable, then the burden is on us to make the migration as effortless as possible." If Google does need to change an API, customers will now get a minimum of one year's notice, along with tools, documentation, and other materials. Google goes on to say "To make sure we follow these tenets, any change we introduce to an API is reviewed by a centralized board of product and engineering leads and follows a rigorous product lifecycle evaluation." Despite being one of the world's biggest Internet companies and basically defining what modern cloud infrastructure looks like, Google just isn't doing very well in the cloud infrastructure market.  Canalys has Google in a distant third with 7 percent market share, behind Microsoft Azure (19 percent) and market leader Amazon Web Services (32 percent). Rumor has it (according to a report from  The Information) Google Cloud Platform is actually facing down a 2023 deadline to beat AWS and Microsoft, or it will risk losing funding.
    Ex-Googler  Steve Yegge laid out the problems with Google Cloud Platform last year in a post titled "Dear Google Cloud: Your Deprecation Policy is Killing You." Google's announcement seems to hit most of what that post highlights, like a lack of documentation and support, an endless treadmill of API upgrades, and Google Cloud's general disregard for backwards compatibility. Yegge argues that successful platforms like Windows, Java, and Android (a group Yegge says is isolated from the larger Google culture) owe much of their success to their commitment to platform stability and never breaking anything. AWS is the market leader partly because it's considered a lot more stable than Google Cloud Platform.
  Protocol reports that Google VP Kripa Krishnan was actually asked during the announcement if she was familiar with the  Killed By Google website and  Twitter account, both run by Cody Ogden. The report says Krishnan "couldn't help but laugh" and said, "It was pretty apparent to us from many sources on the internet that we were not doing well."
 Google Cloud Platform's awareness of Google's reputation, its steps to limit disruption to customers, and its communication of which offerings are more stable than others, feels like a model for the rest of the company. Many Google products currently suffer from the fear that they will be shut down, and oftentimes that's enough for people to seek other alternatives. The primary way to fix this is just  mitigation—i.e., stop shutting  so many things down, all the time. But a close second is communication—just tell people what your plans for future support are.
 Google seems to have no problem offering a public roadmap for the software it ships on hardware devices.  Pixel phones and  Chromebooks both have public support statements for their software, showing a minimum (that's a  minimum!) date that the devices can count on support. For instance, we know a Pixel 5 will continue to receive updates until at least October 2023. Google can't do anything to immediately solve its reputation for killing products and services, but communication like this can help relieve some of the hesitation users and companies increasingly feel when investing in a Google product. If you don't plan on killing a product for a long time, say so! Tell Google users and company partners which products are stable and which ones are fly-by-night experiments.
 Of course, for this to work, Google has to actually  stick to any public commitments it makes so people can trust it will follow through on its promises. Recently, the company did not do this. It promised  three years of support for Android Things, the IoT version of Android. It didn't meet that commitment. Instead, Google ended OS updates after only one year. If Google really wants to fix its reputation for instability, it's going to need a many-year journey.
title: 谷歌云提供了一个模型来修复谷歌的产品扼杀声誉
title_en: Google Cloud offers a model for fixing Google’s product-killing reputation

在普华永道 2021 年 6 月全球消费者洞察脉搏调查中询问的 8,500 多名消费者中，“快速/可靠的交付”是最重要的在线购物属性，这表明交付服务只会在整个电子商务领域变得更加重要。现在消费者已经习惯了当天（和同一时间）送货服务模式，客户对送货选项的期望只会增加。事实上，根据移动应用智能平台 SensorTower 最近的一份报告，顶级外卖应用在 2021 年 1 月和 2 月持续增长，安装量同比增长 14%。然而，尽管用户增长不断攀升，DoorDash、Uber Eats 和 GrubHub 仍然无利可图。那么，商业领袖如何才能设计出满足消费者期望的快速交付模式——同时还能赚钱呢？ “亚马逊支持次日送达，”优步全球食品杂货和新垂直行业负责人 Raj Beri 在 5 月份表示。 “我们将为下一小时的商业提供动力。”但加快交付过程不一定会增加收入。更重要的是，如果您的送货服务导致客户体验不佳，您就不太可能仅仅因为提供更快的送货服务而赢得客户忠诚度。交付应用程序或任何希望将交付服务作为其产品的一部分添加的电子商务公司面临的主要挑战是建立一个基础，不仅为客户提供速度和便利，而且考虑到所有方面客户体验。例如，在运送食物时，负责运送的企业必须确保食物得到安全处理并且没有任何污染物。温度——无论是热的还是冷的——必须在整个交付过程中保持不变，并且订单本身必须正确。一切事物的“优步化”，再加上消费者期望值的大幅提升，要让企业盈利，需要的不仅仅是送货应用程序和司机队伍。为了兑现当日送达服务的承诺，在下订单和出现在客户门口之间，需要做很多事情而不会出现任何失误。交付的产品越复杂，交付过程就越困难。
为了在实现当日交付服务的同时实现盈利，交付应用程序必须考虑满足客户期望所需的技术。它涉及的不仅仅是设计一个应用程序和不断增长的用户数量。真正成功的当日交付模式能够提供卓越的客户体验，它依赖于一个复杂的软件平台，该平台可以同时管理客户旅程的各个方面，同时从客户的角度来看似乎是无缝的。有利可图的送货服务建立在由人工智能系统和机器人技术驱动的自动化系统上。在应用程序和用户增长之前，技术必须是第一位的。任何其他交付商业模式都是把车放在马之前。 Domino's Pizza 是一个品牌，通过将技术作为其商业模式的核心，完善了交付流程并极大地改善了整体客户体验。关键时刻到来了，该品牌将自己定义为一家销售比萨的电子商务公司。它致力于数据应用并实施了一个机器人技术平台，该平台启用了电子交付系统，从而提高了交付过程的速度和效率。 4 月，Domino 开始通过 Nuro 向休斯顿的特定客户推出机器人汽车送货服务。 GrubHub 还采取措施将机器人功能集成到其交付过程中。根据最近的报道，该公司宣布将增加自动驾驶装置，部署类似无人机的机器人为大学生提供食物。该计划将于今年秋季在少数美国大学校园推出，旨在缩短交付时间，并有望降低成本。这种对技术的关注在交付应用程序领域至关重要，或者对于任何被迫在新兴的下一小时商务类别中竞争的企业来说都是至关重要的。建立成功、盈利的商业模式的关键是投资技术平台，这些平台可以连接客户旅程的所有组成部分，从打开应用程序和点击产品到购买产品和安排交付，等等。在一个每个人都想在手机上打开应用程序并在一小时内交付所需的任何东西的世界中，商业领袖很容易专注于交付应用程序本身，无论他们是在构建自己的应用程序还是与其他应用程序合作公司。但专注于应用程序是对当日交付模式的短视。相反，商业领袖必须使用广角镜头并考虑客户旅程的各个方面：客户如何参与他们的业务？客户如何搜索并找到他们提供的产品？完成订单需要什么？在交付订单之前必须满足哪些条件？此外，订单后会发生什么以确保顺利进行并让客户满意？
一些企业正在与交付应用程序合作取得成功，但这伴随着将您的品牌声誉置于另一家作为客户一线员工的公司手中的风险。其他公司正在为其当前的电子商务模型添加交付服务选项，依赖于可以插入现有技术堆栈的第三方软件。不幸的是，这有局限性，对于包含多个组件的受监管企业来说是不可行的。在当天交付服务之上确保无缝客户体验的唯一方法是构建一个专有软件平台，将技术置于您业务的核心，使您能够自动化关键流程，提高交付速度和便利性模型。它还可以集成可以加快订单速度的机器人系统，包括可以加速业务增长的人工智能协议，并随着业务的扩展扩展您的交付模式。 “下一小时交货”是一个吸引人的标语，肯定会在消费者中引起关注，但它是否有助于提高盈利能力还有待观察。作为一家建立了以当日交付服务为中心的盈利商业模式的公司的首席执行官，我怀疑如果支持交付系统的技术缺乏自动化、人工智能和机器人技术。的确，企业将被迫在当天交货方面展开竞争。但自大流行以来出现的另一个事实是，电子商务的新时代带来了更高的客户期望，而仅靠速度是无法满足的。消费者满意度不仅仅取决于将订单从应用程序转移到客户门口所需的时间。为了在送货服务市场取得成功，企业领导者必须问自己一些问题：完成当天送货订单需要他们的哪些业务部分？订购流程是否直观？客户可以监控订单和交货吗？到货时订单是否正确？它是否满足客户的期望？而且，最重要的是，他们的业务是否建立在可以支持整个客户旅程和交付模式的技术平台上，从产品发现和购买到当日交付等等？对这些问题回答“是”的企业是我期望在大流行后世界蓬勃发展的企业。
note_en:
“Fast/reliable delivery” was the most important online shopping attribute among the more than 8,500 consumers queried for  PwC’s June 2021 Global Consumer Insights Pulse Survey, making it clear that delivery services will only become more crucial across the e-commerce landscape.
 Now that consumers have grown accustomed to same-day (and same-hour) delivery service models, customer expectations for delivery options will only increase.
  In fact, according to a  recent report from the mobile app intelligence platform SensorTower, the top food delivery apps saw continued growth in January and February 2021, with installs up 14% year over year. And yet, despite climbing user growth, DoorDash, Uber Eats and GrubHub  remain unprofitable. So how can business leaders design rapid delivery models that meet consumer expectations — and still make money?
    “Amazon powers next-day delivery,” Raj Beri, Uber’s global head of grocery and new verticals,  said in May. “We’re going to power next-hour commerce.”
 But speeding up the delivery process won’t necessarily drive revenue. More importantly, if your delivery service results in a poor customer experience, you’ll be less likely to win customer loyalty just because you offer faster delivery.
 The primary challenge faced by delivery apps, or any e-commerce company looking to add delivery services as part of its offerings, is building a foundation that enables not only speed and convenience for the customer, but one that takes into account all aspects of the customer experience. For example, when delivering food, the business responsible for the delivery must make sure the food is handled safely and remain free of any contaminants. The temperature — whether hot or cold — must be maintained throughout the delivery process and the order itself must be correct.
  The “Uberization” of everything, combined with dramatically elevated consumer expectations, will take much more than a delivery app and fleet of drivers for businesses to be profitable. To follow through on the promise of same-day delivery services, a number of things need to happen without any missteps between when an order is placed and when it shows up at the customer’s door. The more complex the product being delivered, the more difficult the delivery process becomes.
 To enable same-day delivery services while also reaching profitability, a delivery app must take into account the technology needed to meet customer expectations. It involves much more than simply designing an app and growing user numbers. A truly successful same-day delivery model that provides an exceptional customer experience relies on a sophisticated software platform that can simultaneously manage various aspects of the customer journey, all while making it appear seamless from the customer’s point of view.
 Profitable delivery services are built on automated systems powered by artificial intelligence systems and robotics. The technology must come first, before the app and before user growth. Any other delivery business model is putting the cart before the horse.
 Domino’s Pizza is a brand that has perfected the delivery process and vastly improved the overall customer experience by making technology core to their business model. The key moment came when the brand defined itself as an e-commerce company that sells pizza. It committed to data applications and implemented a robotics technology platform that enabled electronic delivery systems that added speed and efficiency to the delivery process. In April, Domino’s began rolling out a  robot car delivery service to select customers in Houston via Nuro.
 GrubHub is also taking steps to integrate robotic capabilities into its delivery process. According to recent  reports, the company announced it would be adding self-driving units that deploy drone-like robots to deliver food to college students. The program, which will roll out on a limited number of U.S. college campuses this fall, aims to reduce delivery times and, hopefully, costs.
 This focus on technology is crucial in the world of delivery apps, or for any businesses forced to compete in the newly emerging category of next-hour commerce. The key to building a successful, profitable business model is to invest in technology platforms that can connect all components of the customer journey, from opening an app and clicking on a product to purchasing the product and scheduling the delivery, and beyond.
  In a world where everyone wants to open an app on their phone and have whatever it is they need to be delivered within an hour, it’s tempting for business leaders to focus on the delivery app itself, whether they are building their own or partnering with another company. But focusing on the app is a shortsighted view of same-day delivery models.
 Instead, business leaders must use a wide-angle lens and consider every single aspect of their customer journey: How do customers engage with their business? How do customers search for and find the products they offer? What does it take to complete an order and what conditions must be met before the order can be delivered? Also, what happens after the order to ensure it went smoothly and to the customer’s satisfaction?
 Some businesses are finding success partnering with delivery apps, but this comes with the risk of putting your brand’s reputation in the hands of another company that acts as a frontline employee with customers. Other companies are adding delivery service options to their current e-commerce model, relying on third-party software that can be plugged into an existing technology stack. Unfortunately, this comes with limitations and is not viable for regulated businesses that include multiple components.
 The only way to ensure a seamless customer experience on top of same-day delivery services is to build a proprietary software platform that puts the technology at the heart of your business, which allows you to automate key processes, adding speed and convenience to your delivery model. It also makes it possible to integrate robotic systems that can expedite orders, include artificial intelligence protocols that can accelerate business growth, and scale your delivery model as your business expands.
  “Next-hour delivery” is a catchy tagline that is sure to gain traction among consumers, but whether it will help drive profitability remains to be seen. As the CEO of a firm that has built a profitable business model centered on  same-day delivery services, I’m skeptical that the promise of next-hour delivery will drive more revenue if the technology powering the delivery systems lacks automation, artificial intelligence and robotics.
 It’s true that businesses will be forced to compete on same-day delivery. But another truth that has emerged since the pandemic is that this new era of e-commerce comes with heightened customer expectations that won’t be met on speed alone. Consumer satisfaction hinges on more than the amount of time it takes to move an order from an app to the customer’s door.
 To succeed in the delivery service market, business leaders must ask themselves a number of questions: Which parts of their business are needed to complete a same-day delivery order? Is the ordering process intuitive? Can the order and delivery be monitored by the customer? Is the order correct when it arrives? Does it meet the customer’s expectations?
 And, most importantly, is their business built on a technology platform that can support the entire customer journey and delivery model, from product discovery and purchase to same-day delivery and beyond? The businesses that answer yes to these questions are the ones I expect to thrive in the post-pandemic world.

   Facebook announced Monday it was forming a new Metaverse product group to advance its efforts to build a 3D social space using virtual and augmented reality tech.
 The big picture: In an  interview with journalist Casey Newton, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said he sees the metaverse — a term widely used in both tech and science fiction to describe broadly shared, open virtual environments — as "the successor to the mobile internet." Zuckerberg also said it was "not something that any one company is going to build."
 Details: Facebook's new Metaverse product group will report to Andrew Bosworth, Facebook's vice president of virtual and augmented reality, who announced the new organization in a  Facebook post.
 What they're saying: Facebook's Oculus and Portal products have been first steps toward the new vision, Bosworth wrote, "but to achieve our full vision of the Metaverse, we also need to build the connective tissue between these spaces — so you can remove the limitations of physics and move between them with the same ease as moving from one room in your home to the next."
 Leading the new team will be Instagram product head Vishal Shah and Facebook Gaming's Vivek Sharma and Jason Rubin.
 Of note: Bosworth's announcement linked to a Facebook hiring page for AR/VR jobs that lists more than 700 openings.
title: Facebook 创建新部门以构建“元界”
title_en: Facebook Creates New Unit To Build a 'Metaverse'

伦敦——在 Uber Eats、Just Eat 和 Deliveroo 的自行车和踏板车之间穿梭于伦敦市中心的一个新进入者承诺几乎可以立即满足您对巧克力或一品脱冰淇淋的渴望：土耳其公司 Getir 表示它会在 10 分钟内运送您的杂货。 Getir 的送货速度来自附近的仓库网络，与该公司最近扩张的惊人速度相匹配。在土耳其开创该模式五年半后，它今年突然在六个欧洲国家开业，收购了一个竞争对手，预计到 2021 年底，将在包括纽约在内的至少三个美国城市开展业务。在短短六个月内，Getir 筹集了近 10 亿美元来推动这次爆发。 “我们加快了去更多国家的计划，因为如果我们不这样做，其他人就会这样做，”Getir 的创始人纳齐姆·萨卢尔说（这个词在土耳其语中是“带来”的意思）。 “这是一场与时间的赛跑。”萨鲁尔先生回头看是对的。仅在伦敦，在过去一年左右的时间里，就有五家新的快速杂货配送公司走上街头。 Glovo 是一家拥有 6 年历史的西班牙公司，提供餐厅餐饮和杂货，在 4 月份筹集了超过 50 亿美元，就在一个月前，总部位于费城的 Gopuff 从包括软银愿景基金在内的投资者那里筹集了 15 亿美元。在大流行期间连续数月在家中关闭，数百万人开始使用在线杂货配送。许多东西的送货订阅量激增，包括葡萄酒、咖啡、鲜花和意大利面。投资者抓住了这一刻，并支持能够为您带来任何您想要的任何东西的公司，不仅仅是很快，而是在几分钟内，无论是婴儿尿布、冷冻披萨还是一瓶冰镇香槟。快速的杂货配送是风投补贴的奢侈品浪潮的下一步，这一代人习惯于在几分钟内订购出租车服务，通过 Airbnb 在廉价别墅中度假，并按需提供更多娱乐。 “这不仅适用于有钱人可以浪费的富人，”萨鲁尔先生说。 “这是一个负担得起的溢价，”他补充道。 “这是一种非常便宜的对待自己的方式。”
外卖行业的盈利之路一直难以捉摸。但根据 PitchBook 的数据，这并没有阻止风险资本家自 2020 年初以来向在线送货杂货业务投资约 140 亿美元。仅今年，Getir 就完成了三轮融资。 Getir 是否有利可图？ “是也不是，”萨鲁尔先生说。他说，一两年后，一个社区就可以盈利，但这并不是说整个公司都已经盈利。 PitchBook 研究食品技术行业的分析师亚历克斯·弗雷德里克 (Alex Frederick) 表示，这个行业似乎正在经历闪电式扩张时期，这个词是由帮助建立 PayPal 并创立 LinkedIn 的里德·霍夫曼 (Reid Hoffman) 创造的，用来描述一家竞相提供服务的公司领先于任何竞争对手的全球客户群。弗雷德里克先生补充说，目前，公司之间存在很多竞争，但没有太大差异。 “这是一场以牺牲盈利能力为代价获得市场份额的竞赛，”他说。 Getir 的第一批主要投资者之一是亿万富翁风险投资家兼红杉资本合伙人迈克尔莫里茨，他以早期对谷歌、PayPal 和 Zappos 的押注而闻名。 “Getir 激起了我的兴趣，因为我还没有听到任何消费者抱怨他们收到订单太快，”他说。 “十分钟交货听起来很简单，但新人会发现筹集资金是业务中最容易的部分，”他说。他说，Getir 花了六年时间——“我们世界的永恒”——解决了它的运营问题。尽管如此，全球各地的城市街道仍然挤满了新兴的杂货配送服务。随着竞争越来越激烈，伦敦的速递公司——比如 Gorillas、Weezy、Dija 和 Zapp——一直在提供非常高的折扣。有一次，Getir 以 10 便士（约 15 美分）的价格提供了价值 15 磅（约 20.50 美元）的食物。
这还不包括已经进入杂货的外卖服务（如Deliveroo）。然后，尽管速度较慢，但​​现在有超市和街角商店提供送货服务，以及亚马逊的超市服务。一旦促销活动结束，用户是否会建立足够强的习惯或足够的品牌忠诚度？最终的利润压力意味着并非所有这些公司都能生存。 Salur 先生说，他并不害怕快速杂货配送方面的竞争，他希望每个国家都有几家企业，就像有竞争的连锁超市一样。在美国等待的是 Gopuff，它已经在 43 个州开展业务，据报道正在寻求 150 亿美元的估值。 59 岁的萨鲁尔在出售关闭的工厂多年后，创业是他职业生涯后期的举动。从那时起，他的重点一直是速度和城市物流。 2015 年，他与另外两名投资者在伊斯坦布尔创立了 Getir，三年后他开发了一款可在三分钟内为人们提供汽车的叫车应用。今年 3 月，当 Getir 融资 3 亿美元时，公司估值为 26 亿美元，成为土耳其的第二家独角兽公司，该术语表示公司估值超过 10 亿美元。如今，该公司的估值为 75 亿美元。在早期，Getir 尝试了两种方法来实现其 10 分钟的目标。方式 1：它将公司的 300 到 400 种产品储存到一直在移动的货车中。但是客户需要的产品数量超过了货车的容量（该公司现在估计最佳数量约为 1,500 件）。面包车交付被放弃。该公司选择了方式 2：通过电动自行车或轻便摩托车从一系列所谓的暗店（仓库和没有顾客的小型超市的混合体）送货，狭窄的过道两旁摆放着杂货的货架。在伦敦，Getir 拥有 30 多家暗店，并已开始在曼彻斯特和伯明翰发货。它每月在英国开设大约 10 家门店，预计到今年年底将开设 100 家门店。 Salur 先生说，更多的顾客意味着更多，而不是更大的商店。挑战在于找到这些房产——它们必须靠近人们的家——然后与不同的地方当局打交道。例如，伦敦分为 33 个这样的委员会，每个委员会都颁发许可证和规划决定。
在伦敦西南部的巴特西，几家黑店的经理维托·帕里内洛 (Vito Parrinello) 决心不让送货员打扰他们的新邻居。黑暗的商店位于铁路拱门下，藏在新开发的公寓后面。在等待的电动滑板车的两侧都有写着“禁止吸烟、禁止大喊、禁止大声音乐”的标志。在里面，你会听到断断续续的钟声，通知工作人员有订单进来。拣货员选择一个篮子，收集物品并将它们装在袋子中供骑手使用。一堵墙上摆满了冰箱，其中一个只放着香槟。任何时候，都有两三个采摘者在过道中穿梭，而在巴特西，气氛平静而安静，这与他们的动作被精确到秒的事实相去甚远。最近一天，打包订单的平均时间为 103 秒。 Parrinello 先生说，缩短交付时间需要商店的效率——它不应该依赖于车手争先恐后地跑向顾客。 “我不希望他们甚至感到在街上奔跑的压力，”他补充道。值得注意的是，Getir 公司的大部分员工都是全职员工，有假期工资和养老金，因为该公司避开了已经引起 Uber 和 Deliveroo 等公司诉讼的零工经济模式。但它为想要灵活性或只寻找短期工作的人提供合同。 “有一种想法是，如果这项工作不是合同，它就无法工作，”萨卢尔先生说。 “我不同意，它会奏效的。”他补充说：“当你看看连锁超市，所有这些其他公司，他们雇佣员工，他们不会破产。”雇用员工而不是承包商会产生忠诚度，但这是有代价的。 Getir 从批发商那里购买产品，然后收取比大型超市价格高 5% 到 8% 的费用。最重要的是，价格并不比当地小型便利店的价格贵多少。 Salur 先生说，在土耳其，95% 的暗店都是独立拥有的特许经营权，并补充说他认为这个系统可以培养出更好的经理。一旦新市场更加成熟，Getir 可能会将这种模式带入新市场。
但这是忙碌的一年。直到 2021 年，Getir 仅在土耳其开展业务。今年，除了英格兰的城市，Getir 还扩展到了阿姆斯特丹、巴黎和柏林。 7 月初，Getir 进行了第一笔收购：Blok，这是另一家在西班牙和意大利经营的杂货配送公司。它仅在五个月前成立。 “这是增长，增长，增长，”萨卢尔先生说。 “这就是我们此刻呼吸的东西。”
note_en:
LONDON — Zipping around central London, among the bikes and scooters of Uber Eats, Just Eat and Deliveroo, is a new entrant promising almost instantaneous satisfaction for your craving for a bar of chocolate or pint of ice cream: Getir, a Turkish company that says it will deliver your groceries in 10 minutes.
 The speed of Getir’s deliveries, from a network of neighborhood warehouses, matches the astonishing pace of the company’s recent expansion. After five and a half years pioneering the model in Turkey, it suddenly opened in six European countries this year, bought a rival and, by the end of 2021, expects to be in at least three American cities, including New York. In just six months, Getir raised nearly $1 billion to fuel this outburst.
 “We accelerated our plans to go to more countries because if we don’t, others do,” said Nazim Salur, a founder of Getir (the word is Turkish for “bring”). “It’s a race against time.”
 Mr. Salur is right to look over his shoulder. In London alone, five new rapid grocery delivery companies have taken to the streets in the past year or so. Glovo, a six-year-old Spanish company that delivers restaurant meals as well as groceries, raised more than half a billion dollars in April, just a month after  Gopuff, based in Philadelphia, raised $1.5 billion from investors, including SoftBank’s Vision Fund.
 Shut at home for months on end during the pandemic, millions of people started using online grocery delivery.   Delivery subscriptions for many things, including wine, coffee, flowers and pasta, surged. Investors have seized this moment and are backing companies that will bring you whatever you desire, not just soon, but within minutes, whether it be baby diapers, frozen pizza or a chilled bottle of champagne.
  Rapid grocery delivery is the next step in the wave of  venture capital-subsidized luxury serving a generation used to ordering taxi services in minutes, vacationing in cheap villas through Airbnb and having ever more entertainment available on demand.
 “This is not just for the rich, the affluent, who have money to waste,” Mr. Salur said. “It’s an affordable premium,” he added. “It’s a very cheap way of treating yourself.”
 The road to profitability has been elusive in the food delivery industry. But that hasn’t stopped venture capitalists from investing about $14 billion in online delivery grocery businesses since the start of 2020, according to data from PitchBook. This year alone, Getir has completed three funding rounds.
 Is Getir profitable? “Yes and no,” Mr. Salur said. After a year or two, a neighborhood can be profitable, he said, which is not to say the company as a whole has been profitable yet.
  Alex Frederick, an analyst at PitchBook who studies the food technology sector, said this industry looked like it was going through a period of  blitzscaling, a term coined by Reid Hoffman, who helped build PayPal and found LinkedIn, to describe a company racing to serve a global customer base before any of its competitors. And right now, there is a lot of competition without much variation among the companies, Mr. Frederick added.
 “It’s a race to get market share at the expense of profitability,” he said.
 One of Getir’s first major investors was Michael Moritz, the billionaire venture capitalist and partner at Sequoia Capital who is famed for early bets on Google, PayPal and Zappos. “Getir piqued my interest because I have yet to hear any consumer complain that they received their order too quickly,” he said.
  “Ten-minute delivery sounds deceptively simple, but the newcomers will discover that raising money is the easiest part of the business,” he said. Getir has spent six years — “an eternity in our world” — solving its operational problems, he said.
 Still, city streets around the globe are crowded with upstart grocery delivery services. As competition gets fiercer, the rapid delivery companies in London — with names like Gorillas, Weezy, Dija and Zapp — have been offering extraordinarily steep discounts. At one point, Getir offered 15 pounds’ (about $20.50) worth of food for just 10 pence (about 15 cents).
  That’s not counting the takeout delivery services that have gotten into groceries (like Deliveroo). And then, albeit at slower speeds, there are the supermarkets and corner stores that now deliver, and Amazon’s supermarket service.
 Will users build up a strong enough habit or enough brand loyalty once the promotions run out? The eventual pressure for profits means not every one of these companies will survive.
  Mr. Salur says he isn’t afraid of competition for quick grocery delivery, expecting there to be several businesses in every country, just as there are competing supermarket chains. Awaiting in America is Gopuff, which is already in 43 states and is reportedly  seeking a $15 billion valuation.
 Entrepreneurship is a late career move for Mr. Salur, 59, after years of selling shuttered industrial plants. Since then, his focus has been speed and urban logistics. He founded Getir in Istanbul in 2015 with two other investors, three years after creating a taxi-hailing app that got cars to people within three minutes. In March, when Getir raised $300 million, which valued the company at $2.6 billion, it became Turkey’s second unicorn, the term for a company valued at more than $1 billion. Today, the company is valued at $7.5 billion.
  In its early days, Getir tried two ways to meet its 10-minute goal. Way 1: It stocked the company’s 300 to 400 offerings into vans that were always on the move. But customers demanded more products than the vans could fit (the company now figures the optimal number is about 1,500 items). Van deliveries were abandoned.
 The company settled on Way 2: delivering via electric bicycles or mopeds from a series of so-called dark stores — a hybrid of warehouse and small supermarket without customers — with narrow aisles lined by shelves stocked with grocery items. In London,  Getir has more than 30 dark stores, and it has begun deliveries in Manchester and Birmingham. It has been opening about 10 stores a month in Britain and expects to have 100 by the end of the year. More customers mean more, not larger, stores, Mr. Salur said.
 The challenge is finding the properties — they must be close to people’s homes — and then dealing with different local authorities. For example, London is divided into 33 such councils, each issuing licenses and planning decisions.
 In Battersea, in southwest London, Vito Parrinello, a manager of several dark stores who until recently managed Italian restaurants, is determined that the delivery riders not disturb their new neighbors. The dark store is under a railway arch, tucked behind a new development of apartments. On either side of the waiting electric scooters are signs that read “No Smoking, No Shouting, No Loud Music.”
 Inside, you hear the intermittent sound of a bell, notifying the staff of an incoming order. A picker selects a basket, collects items and packs them in bags for the rider. A wall is lined with refrigerators, with one stocked solely with champagne. At any one time, two or three pickers are weaving through the aisles, and in Battersea, the atmosphere is calm and quiet, belying the fact that their movements are being measured down to the second. On a recent day, the average time it took to pack an order was 103 seconds.
  Shaving seconds off a delivery requires efficiency in the stores — it shouldn’t rely on riders racing to the customer, Mr. Parrinello said. “I don’t want them to even feel the pressure to run in the streets,” he added.
 Remarkably, most of Getir’s workers companywide are full-time employees with holiday pay and pensions, as the company has shunned the gig economy model that has attracted lawsuits to the likes of  Uber and  Deliveroo. But it offers contracts for people who want flexibility or are looking only for short-term work.
 “There’s this idea that if this work is not contract, it can’t work,” Mr. Salur said. “I beg to differ, it will work.” He added: “When you look at the supermarket chains, all these other companies, they employ people and they don’t go bankrupt.”
 Hiring employees rather than contractors generates loyalty, but it comes at a cost. Getir buys its products from wholesalers and then charges 5 percent to 8 percent more than the prices in a large supermarket. Crucially, the prices aren’t much more expensive than those at small local convenience stores.
 In Turkey, 95 percent of the dark stores are independently owned franchises, Mr. Salur said, adding that he thinks this system produces better managers. It’s a model that Getir might bring to its new markets once they are more established.
 But it has been a busy year. Until 2021, Getir had operated only in Turkey. This year, in addition to the cities in England, Getir has expanded to Amsterdam, Paris and Berlin. At the start of July, Getir made its first acquisition: Blok, another grocery delivery company, which operated in Spain and Italy. It was founded only five months earlier.
 “It’s growth, growth, growth,” Mr. Salur said. “That’s what we breathe at the moment.”

title_en: A look at the rise of ultra-fast grocery delivery startups, some with a goal of 10-minute deliveries, across major cities, led by Turkish startup Getir
